meta.title: Urinary Bladder - Urinary Diversion, Retention of Urine & Incontinence (Part 1)

questions.text: Cause of Brown urine are all EXCEPT?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Beetroot consumption Consumption of large quantities of beetroot can result in red discolouration of the urine. This discolouration is due to the excretion of betalain (betacyanin) pigments such as betanin.

Highyeild:

Discolouration of the urine : Many drugs and foodstuffs have been reported to produce abnormal discolouration of the urine. Most colours have been reported but the most frequently encountered clinically are red/orange and brown. Red Urine : Haematuria, the presence of haem in the urine also produces red discolouration and generates a positive dipstick test. Red urine discolouration due to haemoglobinuria may present in haemolytic disorders such as ‘march haematuria’, classically seen in dehydrated soldiers after prolonged marching. Likewise, myoglobinuria due to myocyte destruction, e.g. caused by rhabdomyolysis after crush injury or compartment syndrome, can also result in red discolouration of the urine. Disordered haem production, seen in porphyria, can result in red discolouration that may change to brown or purple with exposure to sunlight. Consumption of large quantities of beetroot can result in red discolouration of the urine. This discolouration is due to the excretion of betalain (betacyanin) pigments such as betanin. Red/Orange Urine : Several medications can cause red/ orange discolouration of the urine, most commonly rifampicin, isoniazid or phenazopyridine. Others include chlorpromazine, thioridazine, senna and laxatives containing a phenolphthalein component. Brown Urine : The commonly used antibiotics nitrofurantoin and metronidazole can lead to brown urine. Brown urine due to high levels of circulating bilirubin is a feature of obstructive jaundice

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Options: A, B, D. The commonly used antibiotics nitrofurantoin and metronidazole can lead to the urine being discoloured brown. Brown urine due to high-circulating bilirubin is also a feature of obstructive jaundice.

Extraedge:

White urine is a complaint seen in two distinct conditions. One is in young men who may report the presence of a white substance in urine. This substance is usually semen and requires no treatment other than reassurance. The second condition is chyluria where lymphatic fluid, from channels obstructed by filarial inflammation, leaks into the renal pelvicalyceal system

questions.text: The most reliable investigation into bladder rupture is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Retrograde cystogram Retrograde cystography will confirm the diagnosis. It is important to image the patient after drainage of contrast because the full bladder may mask extravasation

Highyeild:

Bladder rupture: This can be intraperitoneal (20%) or extraperitoneal (80%). Intraperitoneal rupture is usually secondary to a blow or falls on a distended bladder, and more rarely to surgical damage. Extraperitoneal rupture is caused by blunt trauma or surgical damage. Gross haematuria can be absent. It may be difficult to distinguish extraperitoneal rupture from rupture of the membranous urethra. Intraperitoneal rupture is associated with sudden severe pain in the hypogastrium, often accompanied by syncope. The shock subsides and the abdomen distends and there is no desire to micturate. Peritonitis does not follow immediately if the urine is sterile; varying degrees of rigidity is present on examination. Investigations : Retrograde cystogram or CT cystogram confirms the diagnosis and identifies whether the injury is intraperitoneal or extraperitoneal. Postdrainage views should be obtained as a small amount of contrast extravasation may be missed with a full bladder. With intraperitoneal perforation, contrast is seen to outline loops of bowel

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Intravenous urography (IVU) may confirm a leak. Option: B. Computed tomography (CT) is ideal. Plain erect radiographs may show a ground-glass appearance (fluid).

questions.text: A 50-year- male presents with complaints of painless terminal haematuria, loss of weight and appetite. On examination, the abdomen is soft, with no tenderness, guarding or rigidity. On further evaluation, muscle-invasive bladder cancer was diagnosed. Radical cystectomy followed by urinary diversion. Which of the following is the most commonly used diversion procedure?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ileal conduits

Highyeild:

Ileal conduits are the most commonly used diversion procedure. It is an external diversion procedure Urinary diversion can lead to stricture at the anastomosis, reflux of urine, reabsorption of solutes leading to dys-electrolytemia Male patients should be counselled about the onset of erectile dysfunction and anejaculation after the operation, although in some cases the nerve supply for erectile function can be preserved through careful dissection; they should also be told about alternative forms of urinary diversion, which include continent urinary diversions and orthotopic bladder replacement. Gold standard conduit for urinary diversion: Ileal conduit An ileal conduit is best for urinary diversion as it is simplest to perform and associated with minimal intra-operative and immediate post-operative complications.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. It is an internal permanent diversion method. Here ureters are anastomosed to the sigmoid colon Option: C. It is a permanent internal diversion, neobladder is created using the ileum and the ureter is anastomosed Option: D. It is a permanent internal diversion, the neobladder is created using the caecum and the ureter is anastomosed

Extraedge:

Alternative for Urinary Diversion: Orthotopic bladder substitute Heterotopic bladder substitute or ureterosigmoidostomy

questions.text: A 60-year- female presents with haematuria. Urine examination revealed RBCs. Cystoscopy revealed irregular growth. A biopsy of the growth revealed squamous cell carcinoma. The patient underwent radical cystectomy with ileal conduit diversion. Which of the following is the most common complication of ileal conduits?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Stricture The stricture is most common in the left ureter and is usually found as the ureter crosses over the aorta beneath the inferior mesenteric artery. OTHER COMPLICATION Ureteroileal leak Stomal complications such as stenosis or hernia Upper tract dilatation Recurrent UTIs Metabolic complications (hyperchloraemic metabolic acidosis).

questions.text: A 20 year came with complaints of abdominal pain, fever and vomiting. On examination abdomen is soft, and right iliac fossa tenderness is present. On further evaluation, acute appendicitis was diagnosed. An appendicectomy was done. Postoperatively patient developed retention of urine, hence catheterized. With regards to a catheter which of the following is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Fr is the inner diameter of the catheter

questions.correct_answer: C. 16Fr is the most commonly used
questions.explanation:
Solution:

16Fr is the most commonly used 14/16fr catheter is the most commonly used.

Highyeild:

The immediate treatment for urinary retention of any cause is urethral catheterisation Types : Based on size : 12Fr 14Fr(Women) 16Fr(men) 22Fr(haematuria with clot retention) Based on channels : Single channel Two-channel (Foley Cather - Standard One) Three-way catheter Composition : Latex coated Silicone Urethral Catheterisation Suprapubic Catheterisation

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Options: A. Fr is the outer diameter of the catheter Options: B. 1Fr=0.33mm

Extraedge:

Coudé tip catheters have a curved tip to allow easier passage past an enlarged prostate.

questions.text: A 50-year- male presents with urinary incontinence and burning micturition. On examination, the abdomen is soft, with no tenderness, guarding, or rigidity. Which of the following is not a cause of urinary incontinence?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rectovaginal fistula

Highyeild:

Urinary incontinence is defined as the involuntary leakage of urine Classification Stress urinary incontinence (SUI) (involuntary leakage of urine secondary to increased intra-abdominal pressure, e.g. coughing, sneezing); Overactive bladder (OAB); urinary urgency, usually with urinary frequency and nocturia, with or without urinary incontinence Mixed urinary incontinence (combination of both OAB and SUI). Causes : Multiparity; Childbirth complications and vaginal delivery; Rising female age - menopause; Vesicovaginal fstulae; Urethral diverticulum/congenital anomalies, e.g. ectopic ureters; Immobility, constipation or urinary tract infection; Chronic medical conditions, e.g. congestive heart failure, diabetes mellitus, multiple sclerosis; Medications, e.g. loop diuretics; Secondary to pelvic masses; Obesity and weight gain. Presentation : Storage symptoms: Frequency (increased frequency of more than eight times during the day) Urgency Nocturia (increased frequency of voiding more than once a night) Emptying symptoms: Hesitancy Slow stream Incomplete emptying Straining to urinate Urinary leakage with exertion/coughing Haematuria (in women >40 years of age, additional investigations should be performed to rule out malignancy Investigations : Urinary incontinence-specific symptom and quality of life questionnaire, including a bladder diary; Digital examination; Urine analysis and a midstream urine sample for microscopy, culture and sensitivity; Urodynamics, including an assessment of postvoid residual volumes – if conservative measures have failed, the type of incontinence is unclear or there is a recurrence of symptoms following surgical intervention; Ultrasound of the kidneys, ureters and bladder in patients with recurrent urinary tract infections/haematuria; Cystoscopy if pathology is suspected. Management : Management options for overactive bladder (OAB) . Conservative • Lifestyle changes (i.e. limit fluid intake, avoid diuretics such as tea/coffee, weight loss) • Behavioural modification (e.g. bladder drills) for a minimum of 6 weeks • Review of coexistent medications (e.g. diuretics) • Pelvic floor training (physiotherapy) for at least 3 months, comprising at least eight contractions three times per day • Bladder catheterisation-intermittent self catheterisation if increased post void residuals Medical therapy • Anticholinergics (e.g. oxybutynin [avoid in elderly frail women at risk of cognitive impairment], tolterodine); side effects include a dry mouth and constipation • Selective ẞ3-adrenoreceptor agonist (e.g. mirabegron) for the management of urge incontinence • Desmopressin specifically used to treat symptoms of nocturia Surgical • Intravesical botulinum toxin A • Neuromodulation (tibial nerve stimulation or sacral neuromodulation) • Bladder reconstruction (augmentation cystoplasty - risks include bowel disturbance, metabolic acidosis, mucus production and/or retention in the bladder, urinary tract infection, urinary retention and malignancy) • Urinary diversion only when non-surgical management has failed and if botulinum toxin type A, percutaneous sacral nerve stimulation and augmentation cystoplasty are not appropriate or are unacceptable

questions.text: A 75- year- old male presented to the emergency with sudden onset of abdominal pain and distension. No clinical sign of peritonitis. Bystander gives a history of not passing urine for 12 hours. USG showed a distended bladder. Which is the most common cause of the above presentation.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bladder outlet obstruction The most frequent causes of acute retention Male: Bladder outlet obstruction (the most common cause) Urethral stricture (Option D) Acute urethritis or prostatitis Phimosis (Option C) Female: Retroverted gravid uterus Bladder neck obstruction (rare) (Option A) Both: Blood clot Urethral calculus Rupture of the urethra Neurogenic (injury or disease of the spinal cord) Smooth muscle cell dysfunction associated with ageing Faecal impaction Anal pain (haemorrhoidectomy) Intensive postoperative analgesic treatment Some drugs Spinal anaesthesia
